summary: This is a Department of Justice Office of the Inspector General (OIG) memorandum providing a status update on the Federal Bureau of Prisons' (BOP) implementation of recommendations from a June 2023 OIG report on the custody, care, and supervision of Jeffrey Epstein at the Metropolitan Correctional Center. It details the BOP's responses and the OIG's analysis for eight specific recommendations aimed at improving inmate safety and operational procedures.

persons.name: Jeffrey Epstein
persons.context: The deceased inmate whose custody and death at the Metropolitan Correctional Center prompted the original OIG investigation and the subsequent recommendations this document addresses.

events.title: OIG Status Update Memorandum
events.description: The OIG issued this memorandum analyzing the BOP's July 2024 update, noting that seven recommendations remain 'Resolved' and one is now 'Closed'.

locations: Metropolitan Correctional Center in New York, New York
keyFacts: The OIG's original June 2023 report made eight recommendations to the BOP following its investigation into Jeffrey Epstein's custody and death.

As of this August 2024 update, Recommendations 1-6 and 8 remain 'Resolved' (meaning the BOP has responded but the OIG is awaiting final implementation), while Recommendation 7 regarding cell search procedures is now 'Closed'.
Multiple recommendations focus on improving procedures for inmates on suicide watch, including assigning cellmates, managing visits, and enhancing accountability for inmate whereabouts.

The BOP is in the process of revising several key Program Statements (e.g., 5500.14, 5500.15, 4200.12) and drafting new guidance in response to the recommendations, but these are still under review or union negotiation.
The BOP reported implementing a new Security Camera Monthly Report effective June 1, 2024, as an immediate action to address camera system functionality.
